10101C_Intro: ^You awaken to a pounding on your door.
^EVERICH: Leech! It's my young Adda, she's ill!

g-0: ^Though it's before dawn, you rise and greet the worried family. The father, Everich, carries a young girl to the table and sets her down atop it.

^The work of the village Leech is never done, it seems. You've spent your days healing the aches and pains of these people for nearly four winters now, yet new ailments seem to grow on trees out in the swampy wilderness.

10102I_AddaExam: ^You turn your attention back to the girl, Adda. She lies on the table, shivering and groaning in pain.

s: ^Her arms...
^Her neck...

c-0: ^You catch sight of a dark red bruise. Then another.
^Something about them feels off. Her father might know more.
c-1: ^She has a growth. A pustule a bit larger than a pea, angry and red. You've never seen anything quite like it before.

firstInteraction: ^EVERICH: Have you ever seen anything like this?

s: ^LEECH: I've read about similar ailments, but never personally treated anything like this, no.
^LEECH: It's quite odd, I must admit. But there must be a tincture or salve for it...
^LEECH: Can't say that I have. Hundreds of broken bones or terrible gashes, but never a growth like this.
^LEECH: I've seen all sorts of ailments, Everich. No need to worry.
^LEECH: Yes, many times. I know just the thing for it.

s: ^LEECH: When did she begin to exhibit symptoms?

10105I_TreatingAdda: ^It's clear to see that she's suffering from a form of dyscrasia — an imbalance of the humors — but that appears to be a symptom of something greater.
^She has an excess of blood, proven by her fever, bruising, and those terrible red growths.

s0: ^charlatan:Perhaps it would be best to lance them, but the girl is already in pain and it might be best to let her body fight on its own. The common response for excessive blood is bloodletting, but this may be an uncommon situation.
s1: ^This is unlike anything you've "healed" before, and you're not sure how many more times you can say it was "the Lady's will" that your patient died. But each remedy you administer is a gamble, and you're feeling lucky.

s: ^REMEDY: Tincture for Fever, Pain, & Pustules
^REMEDY: Leeches
^REMEDY: Bloodletting
^REMEDY: Unicorn Horn Panacea

tincture: ^You gather the ingredients - the last of your mandragora root, dried coriander, and redcurrants - and brew a tea.
^Your supplies are running low. You make a salve using the last of your mandragora. You apply it to the pustules and get to work brewing a tea that should help with the fever.
^It's not much, but you are hesitant to let her blood at this stage, whether by leech or blade.
^You send the girl's father home with instructions to return at sunrise. With your medicinals administered, all anyone can do is wait.

c-0: ^You pass the time combing through your books for any sort of similar ailment. You've never seen anything like this, and it seems nobody else has either.

^The girl's condition steadily worsens, despite your best efforts. The pustules on her neck burst in a gory spray and her fever is nigh unstoppable. You wrap her neck to stop the bleeding, but the illness has done its work.
^Adda passes just as the sun rises, mere moments before her father arrives.

^It's never easy to watch someone lose a loved one, but it is by no means a new experience for you. You give the grieving father the privacy he needs and decide to collect payment for your services some other time.
^Once Everich leaves, you must as well. You need to gather more supplies.

leeches: ^The ceramic lid of the jar is cold when you lift it. The wriggling shapes inside stir when you disturb them.

b: ^You pick out three, that should do the trick.
^You pick out ten, half the amount you would use on an adult.
^EVERICH: Is it necessary to use that many of them?
^EVERICH: And you think this will work?

s: ^LEECH: It may seem like a lot, but each only sucks a small amount of blood. And she has quite an excess of it at the moment.
^LEECH: Do you want her to get better?
^LEECH: Yes, the leeches will suck her excess blood, but won't put her at risk of losing too much.
^LEECH: I hope so.

c-3: ^EVERICH: Well, that's hardly a comfort, Leech.
g-0: ^The leeches latch onto the girl's arms easily. Now you must simply wait for them to

b: ^work their magic
^do their work

leechesPhysician: ^Adda hasn't been lucid the entire morning, but she drifts into slumber just a few minutes later - as does her father, slumped in a chair nearby.
^The leeches detach when their bellies are full and you place them back in the jar as dawn arrives. These leeches will be satisfied for months, you will need new, hungrier ones soon.

leechesFailure: ^You expect the girl to settle as her humors come into balance, but her condition continues to deteriorate. The fever worsens, as does her pain. Adda's struggling weakens and weakens until she falls unconscious.

bloodletting: ^Rooting out the problem at the apparent source is the most direct route to a solution.

s: ^LEECH: Hold her still. I'm going to drain those growths.

c-0: ^Everich gently grabs her shoulders. After a moment, her squirming ceases. Perfect.
^You carefully slice the skin of each pustule with your lancet. Dark, sick blood, pours from the cuts. It almost smells sour.
^You press a bowl to the steady flow of blood. The wounds must drain until the blood runs clean.
^Everich passes you a new bowl when you ask for it. He hesitates as you hand him the bowl full of blood.
^EVERICH: Leech... what am I to do with this?

b: ^Suddenly you miss the busy clinic back in the city.
^Suddenly you miss Old Gritta and your days as her apprentice.
^Suddenly you miss the battlefield, mercenaries make much better assistants.
^You can't help but relate.
